http://www.theborneopost.com/2017/05/12/pu...ified-from-dun/KUCHING: The august House here today voted in favour of a ministerial motion to disqualify Dr Ting Tiong Choon (DAP-Pujut) from the State Legislative Assembly (DUN).DUN Speaker Datuk Amar Mohd Asfia Awang Nassar announced that 70 honorable members voted for while 10 voted against the motion.“I hereby declared that the ministerial motion in the name of Minister of International Trade and E-Commerce Dato Sri Wong Soon Koh is approved.“The honorable member for Pujut is hereby disqualified under Article 17(1)(g) of the State Constitution as a member of the House and ceases to be a member of the House forthwith. The sitting is adjourned to 2.30pm,” Asfia said as he made the ruling in the DUN Chamber.Prior to the vote, a heated debate between the ruling and opponent benches took place during Wong’s winding up speech.Wong asked Dr Ting to confirm whether he had acquired Australian citizenship, to which the DAP man said he was not obligated to prove that since Wong was the one who raised the allegation.“I’m not the one who alleged it. So you need to prove it to me. Would you ask member for Batu Kawa (Datuk Dr Sim Kui Hian) whether he has Australian citizenship?” quipped Dr Ting.Asfia then rose to Wong’s defence by pointing out that “this is not a motion against Bawang Assan (Wong) but it’s against you.”Wong was asked to proceed with his winding up and he advised Dr Ting: “Do not try to mislead this House anymore. Do not try to confuse anyone.”An opposition member or two could have challenged Wong to repeat the issue outside the dewan as the minister was heard saying: “I will do it. Don’t challenge me. I will do it.”Wong cautioned that such a challenge would only “land Dr Ting in hot water” as he insisted that he had concrete evidence that Dr Ting had accepted Australian citizenship on Jan 20, 2010.With Dr Ting’s disqualification, the Pujut seat is now vacant now and a by-election should be called within 60 days.

http://www.sinarharian.com.my/edisi/sabah-...awatan-1.673582KUCHING - Status Dr Ting Tiong Choon sebagai Adun Pujut digugurkan hari ini kerana memegang kewarganegaraan Australia.Menurut laporan Borneo Post, usul pelucutan tersebut dibentang Menteri Perdagangan Antarabangsa dan E-Dagang, Datuk Seri Wong Soon Koh pada persidangan Dewan Undangan Negeri (Dun) Sarawak, hari ini.Sebelum pengundian dibuat, Wong mendakwa beliau mempunyai bukti konkrit yang menunjukkan Dr Ting menerima kewarganegaraan Australia pada 20 Januari, 2010.Pengundian kemudian dijalankan.Speker Dun, Datuk Amar Mohd Asfia Awang Nassar mengumumkan 70 anggota Adun menyokong usul Dr Wong, manakala 10 yang lain menentang."Status keahlian Adun Pujut kini digugurkan berdasarkan Perkara 17 (1) (g) Perlembagaan Negeri, Kata Asfia.Pilihan Raya Kecil (PRK dijangka dijalankan di kawasan berkenaan dalam tempoh 60 hari.

Wong stands by claims against sacked Pujut repPETRA JAYA: State International Trade and E-Commerce Minister Datuk Seri Wong Soon Koh stood by his claims against Pujut assemblyman Dr Ting Tiong Choon, in that the latter is a bankrupt and holds dual citizenship.He backed his claims by producing two documents to support his allegations.One of the two documents is a letter by Bukit Aman Criminal Investigation Department (CID) responding to Wong’s enquiry over Dr Ting’s alleged Australian citizenship.The letter dated May 4, 2017 was signed by Bukit Aman CID director Datuk Seri Mohmad Salleh.The letter stated that, police, based on confirmation in writing by the Australian Federal Police, found that Dr Ting had acquired Australian citizenship on Jan 20, 2010.The letter also stated Dr Ting had renounced his Australian citizenship on Apr 4, last year, about a month before the 11th state election.The second document produced by Wong was a report of Bankruptcy Register Search (BRS) from the Australian Financial Security Authority.BRS contains personal insolvency information about individuals, which is derived from the National Personal Insolvency Index in Australia.Based on the report extracted on July 2 last year, about two months after the May 5 state polls, Wong said Dr Ting was declared a bankrupt twice in 2012.“I did the search on Dr Ting’s financial status last year. From 2012 until 2016, he had never settled his debts as his name was in the list,” Wong told reporters, here today.Wong, moved a ministerial motion to disqualify Dr Ting during the state assembly sitting last Friday.Dr Ting, a general medical practitioner by profession, was disqualified after 70 assemblymen voted in favour of the motion. Only 10 assemblymen voted against.

Dual passport holders automatically lose M'sian citizenship: DPMA Malaysian will automatically lose his Malaysian citizenship if he is found to have dual citizenship, Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Ahmad Zahid Hamidi said yesterday.He said the Constitution clearly states that a Malaysian would lose his citizenship once he becomes a citizen of another country."We have to look at the laws of our country, especially the highest legislation, which is the Federal Constitution which only recognises one citizenship for Malaysians."If any Malaysian has dual citizenship, he or she will automatically lose the Malaysian citizenship (or if) he or she has applied to be a citizen of another country," he said when asked to comment on the Sarawak legislative assembly disqualifying Pujut assemblyman Dr Ting Tiong Choon of the DAP for allegedly having Australian citizenship.Zahid said the decision of the Sarawak Assembly could be challenged or brought to court by the relevant political party. Nevertheless, the Federal Constitution must be upheld as the leading legal reference and respected by all."This is not a question of politicising an issue, but a question of principle upheld by the legislative system and the people of Malaysia," he said.The Sarawak assembly disqualified Dr Ting as the assemblyman for Pujut on May 12 citing his alleged Australian citizenship. DAP secretary-general Lim Guan Eng, however, claims that the assembly had abused its authority to disqualify Dr Ting, and that the matter will be brought to court. -- BERNAMA

Obviously he can't stay in UK indefinitely if he's not a citizen. He doesn't have the same privilege RPK has.What you're asking is for his citizenship as a Malaysian to be revoked and to leave him stateless. Does that even make sense to you just because you don't agree with his politics? The only reason the government would get involved would be on the question of citizenship and not his position as a politician. He's still a Malaysian and he hasn't given that up. Intention aside, he's doing a lot more for the country than most of us in /k. Is it really hard for you to accept that a person's goals and intentions can change? Giving up citizenship is not betraying the country or disrespecting the King.And he's not representing you. He's not representing me either. It's up to the people he's representing to decide that but you're asking for a higher authority to do that on your behalf.Intention to swap loyalty is not swapping loyalty. He hasn't changed his citizenship but you're arguing as if he had. You're equating intention with carrying it out.

When all else fails, make personal attacks. I'd like to think I'm loyal enough.in·ten·tionin?ten(t)SH(?)n/Submitnoun1.a thing intended; an aim or plan."she was full of good intentions"He did not break any laws by applying for citizenship in another country. He's not representing you either because you're not his constituent and he's an ADUN so he doesn't affect you at the federal level. You can chide him for his wrong intentions all you want but the fact remains that he's still a citizen of this country and he has the same rights as you do. Denying him that when he's a full Malaysian citizen would be contravening the Constitution. At this point, you're just making up his thought process to justify your claims that he's a traitor. Trying to equate his application with disrespecting the King is far-fetched and it seems like you're using it as a defense in hopes that people would be afraid of reprisals, especially from the authorities.You're still refusing to accept that he might've had a change of heart. Even criminals get a second chance. Are you expecting everyone who has worked or lived overseas in the past to not get involved in our politics?

column8: tapi pokoknya aku x claim siapa2 innocent ?

It's not like we can make laws perfectly aligned with morality. There is spirit behind each law, so if we understand why some laws are written that way, we could certain actions that go against that spirit is not commendable even if doesn't break the law literally.The spirit behind not having dual citizenship is that we want to ensure loyalty to the nation. Being loyal means you care about its welfare. If your loyalty is suspect, then we can't trust that you will work for our betterment.About giving criminals second chance: I agree if it's about the giving the said criminal a new job to ensure he can make a living. But this is a matter of choosing a leader. I'm pretty sure there are still more candidates that you don't have to risk choosing a guy with a questionable background. Or you'd prefer a devil you know rather than an angel you don't?
